entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
I love modularity, and that extends into video games! Not every video game is going to be custom made for my interest, as most things aren't, however thanks to mods, I can tweak things to be a little bit more catered towards my interest, being mostly clientside skins as a starting thing, to grander projects such as modding New Vegas or adding my fursona as a playable character in Fallout 4.

In regards to why I use those sites specifically: Popularity, mostly. Nexus specifically has made a stance regarding pride flags in games that I appreciated (that being that any mods removing them are considered hate speech and won't be tolerated), however for most other platforms, its popularity. The more popular a platform is, the more mods will be listed.

platformsUseReasonAsUserCategory.description: Enjoy customizing games to cater to personal interests and preferences.
Choose platforms based on popularity, which can indicate the number and variety of mods available.
Appreciate platforms that take a stance on certain issues, such as prohibiting hate speech.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: If that money is worth being used for the subscription. Being a full time university student living an hour away from her university, money has to be stretched JUST to arrive on campus daily. When considering getting a subscription service, I need to consider if that money would be better spent on gas money or if I can spare the money monthly for a service I rely on day to day (i.e. Spotify, mainly, and only thanks to the half-off student deal I get).

subscriptionDecisionMainFactorCategory.description: Price, cost-benefit analysis, affordability, and value for money, including comparisons to existing expenses such as university expenses, minimum wage, gas, and other subscriptions

entries.platformsUseReasonAsModder:
Mainly because I try to upload wherever is most convenient for players to access them. Since Curseforge made it easy to create and distribute Minecraft Modpacks, it was the obvious choice. I don't mod Minecraft anymore, however. If I were to go back to it, I'd probably host my mods on Modrinth nowadays, since it's way more user focused than Curseforge currently is.

I feel as a mod developer, or even just a developer in general my goal is to make mods or software for the best interest of users. If I make mods or software that a user has a hard time accessing or using, then I have failed.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
No. This is a modding platform. Unless I make mods, I don't care about flashy profile stuff or stuff. The bare minimum I would care about is user-custom profile pictures, which should be avalible to everyone. QoL and better download speed should be avalible to everyone too, I shouldn't think about buying a subscription because I am annoyed with slow speeds or an annoying feature. If an application is annoying me, I will be less inclined to support it. Early access features would be fine, but a beta branch for more people to participate in would be better. That is the point of beta testing, to get more feedback. A way to support creators and a premium mod test releases would be cool, but I think that shouldn't be apart of a subscription. That should be done by the mod creator, so they can how much they cost. Adding a way for mod devs to add donation/premium purchases on their mod page, handled by this site? Would be awesome! Just not a website wide subscription. I think ads are the best way. As long as they aren't intrusive. Annoying, but don't affect the overral experience. That's my take on things.

-Z, a thunderstore user for Risk of Rain 2

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser: Thunderstore is easy to use through the r2modmanager. Steam Workshop is easy to use as it is integrated with the Steam platform (although its installed mod management features leave a lot to be desired). Nexusmods is generally the most populated site for modding most games.

entries.reasonForNotWillingToDonateOther: I feel like introducing money to the modding scene has significant negative effects on the modding and gaming community as a whole. Modding neccessitates building upon others work as you are editing a completed product. After that, most mods are not created in a vaccuum, and rely on frameworks made by or information gathered by others. Modders going closed source and refusing to share knowledge in an attempt to secure an income stream can easily kill a games modding community, or prevent one from even forming.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
well it truly depends on what I'm getting, if I'm juts getting no adds, fast download speeds and exclusive features then I'm not buying it or even conceding it. 

but if the subscription where to have account/ profile customization, early access to upcoming mods (mods in development), early access to new platform features, and in addition with removal of adds and possibly faster download speeds (although it isn't necessary in the slightest).

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: I don't have any subscriptions. I avoid them like the plague. Its single payment or bust for me.

subscriptionDecisionMainFactorCategory.description: Aversion to subscriptions or subscription-based business models, including preferences for free or one-time payment models

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser: Because these are the best and/or sometimes the only reliable way to get the mods I want for the games I play. Thunderstore for Valheim, Curseforge for Minecraft/WoW, and Steam for Ark/Conan, and Nexus for Skyrim SE/Fallout 4. If there were other well-known platforms that were reliable, I would check them out too, but I mosly like to stick to one place if I can. For example, Arthmoor moving most of his mods to AFKmods when Nexus changed their policy (which benefits us mod-users when making modpacks, which I do) complicated things abit for me. I worry about things like my information getting out, spyware/malaware/etc. when downloading mods after what happened with WoW/Curseforge and Total RP3, so if everything could get put into one place with minimal ads flying around that would be great. Half the ads I see are questionable at best and downright malicious at most, and that's why I don't like them, so obviously I will stick to places with fewer ads, just like everyone else really. Remembering downloading mods from Minecraft's Forum back in the day, where everytime you clicked on a page you got literally smacked with a huge ad that would sometimes break the page. Oh how I hate that crap... Just... Keep the ads minimal and to a minimum if you want your users to be content. Ease of use and low-learning curve with pretty UI's are preferred when it comes to modding and the sites for it. Integration between the site and mod manager are also great. Just don't be like nexus, making Vortex and wanting everyone to use it, when its overly complicated and hard to use, when everyone just uses MO2 instead because... Well, its way better in just about every way. Sometimes simpler is better.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: TBH, I ask myself "is this worth it, and SHOULD I be able to access this content for free?" as in "are they paywalling me, or are they just offering me cool side perks?" and "are they purposefully mombarding me with ads just so I can buy their premium?" and finally: "IS THIS WORTH MY HARD-EARNED MONEY IN TIMES LIKE THIS?" If any of these questions get a latter answer, I will not be buying. It's the same reason why I will never buy YouTube premium: There's SO MANY ADS that it literally ruined YouTube forever for me, so no, they are not getting my money. I understand I could change that by paying them what? $15 a month? But if they weren't purposfully ruffling my feathers with a rediculous amount of ads in the first place, and only charged like $5-10, then maybe I'd think about it. But a bad model warrants monetary consideration, doesn't it?

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
Thunderstore is pretty decent because I use "R2ModMan" as my mod manager to manage mods for Risk of Rain 2 as well as Valheim. Works pretty well. I wish Thunderstore had more detailed mod pages though, like Nexus mods does (description, files, images, videos tabs etc.)

Nexus mods is a great site, their only downside is their speed-limited downloads for non-premium members, and recently removing lifetime premium membership. Other than that their layout is great, filters are great, site works great.

Curseforge I use for Minecraft. Its layout leaves a lot to be desired, but it works pretty decently as a one-click-install site for mods, texture packs, worlds and more.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
It's value proposition: how much it costs versus what I get out of it, and what I lose by not getting it.

If it's way too expensive for little gain, it's not worth it. If it's basically necessary to even use the platform, I just go to a different platform. If its reasonable and I get good features, I would consider it if I use the platform often.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
Thunderstore has a very seamless integration with a lot of games thanks to launchers like r2modman.
Nexusmods is my least favorite platform, but a lot of mods reside on there, so I'm kind of forced to use it.
GameBanana has a great community and a huge catalog of mods.
The Steam Workshop has a very direct integration with games that do support it, so it makes it easy to check and install community content.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: How much of that money goes into supporting the mod creators vs supporting the platform--it should be a balance ofc, with mod creators getting the higher end. Also keeping the actual content (the mods) available to free users who potentially cannot afford to pay for another subscription, but offering ad-free browsing, cosmetic features, & early access (at the control of mod creators) to mods included in a subscription. I think it is vital for the gaming community not to be forced into paying for mods, but giving them an avenue to pay a small, affordable amount in order to maintain upkeep for the site. Also having a donate button for all mod creators and a donate button specifically for the platform for additional one time payment support would contribute to my personal decision.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsModder: Thunderstore is the dedicated place to mod our game, the community has agreed upon it. However, to give Thunderstore credit, it is far simpler to upload there than it is on NexusMods. On the other hand, Bonetome had an easier interface, with in-house tools to update the description of the modpage (without needing to reupload the mod entirely), as well as the means to upload videos/images with the upload page, rather than hyperlink know-how. I think if Thunderstore gets the same tools as Bonetome it would finally succeed it, at least in my eyes as a mod creator.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
Okay, those ideas in regards to a subscription, only 3 of them were good. The rest are consumer unfriendly, some dependent on the modmakers to deliver the chores of a subscription service. It should really be kept simple with a focus on ads vs no ads, and it really should not become as predatory as Nexus with download throttling and/or caps. 

All that being said, I do not feel opted to get the subscription anyway. I do not mind seeing advertisements, and I feel the amount of mods I've uploaded on Thunderstore is my means of showing my support to you guys. When the mod manager gets to that point where it has answered all of these issues I've had since I've started using it (the main three being downloads from the mod manager slower than the website, on page readme support, easier video / image hosting), and it doesn't flip a coin and become a clone of Nexus, only then is when I'd opt into the subscription service. Updates throughout 2021 -- 2022 have been slow and sparse, so I'm not going to hold my breath over these changes happening.

entries.interstInModdingProfessionOther: I see RoR2 characters get commissioned for $200-$400 dollars. Even with my skillset, assuming I giga grind and pump out 1 character commission per week, I'm not even making minimum wage doing it fulltime. Additionally, trying to front the cost into other methods (ex. loading up the modloader with ads, donator benefits for mods, etc.) only serves to piss off the end user. Voluntary donations are the most user-friendly, but I doubt it's enough to make a living off of, and after seeing the disgusting behavior of XoXFaby with his handling of BetterUI, I made sure to remove the option to donate on my mods lest I be associated with someone like him. Modders and fan translators are notorious for getting obnoxious with donation begging on certain platforms, and I have no doubt that a creator fund or something similar would only encourage this type of behavior from grifters who do nothing but showcase their epic models and screenshots of giga mods that will never actually see a real release.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
LMAO no.
Mods have been free for the past 30 years and should remain free. Creators are well within their right to ask for donations for their work but asking for money introduces too many hurdles to the modding community, as well as opening creators to legal problems down the line.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: Whether the convenience of the cost is worth getting the product legitimately. Nothing is safe from piracy these days and if the convenience (which is honestly the main thing people are paying for with a sub, you CAN get your movies, games etc for free elsewhere) of use is neglected or downright fought against by whatever model is being used to monetize, that sub will just be replaced with a torrented one somewhere else, more negatively impacting everyone involved. Please keep this in mind when monetizing the Thunderstore project. I do not wish to see you end up in a hole like so many other subscription services that have lost huge amounts of money because they forgot about or neglected their actual paying users.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser: Thunderstore is my favorite external solution, Steam Workshop being the most convenient and easy-to-use overall. Nexus simply has the biggest mod collection and game support, despite being the worst otherwise, I can't stand their capped downloads and Vortex is really only good for a small percentage of the games they support. Mod.io is nice honestly, I simply much prefer Steam Workshop for the use case of in-game mod support.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
If it's purely for donation and supporting a creator, then there isn't really factors to note of. If it's for features, (say more download speed, features, qol, etc.) I actively don't purchase.

Subscriptions should purely be for cosmetic bonuses that others can see (like a silly dumb badge, animated profile pictures, profile picture frames, banners, name colors, custom emojis).

Things like file size limitations (cough cough discord), QOL features, client-side only content, etc. should not be in a subscription model UNLESS said content is for hardcore users (IE: say the file size limit by default is like 20 GB, but it's 500 GB for subscribers, that's fine since 90% of modders aren't gonna reach file sizes of that scale and those who do have a actual reason to pay).

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: When I was in highschool I purchased a lifetime subscription to Nexus mods which uncapped download speeds and gives you access to better download servers. I modded and still mod games all the time and very regularly download large game overhauls or reworks, it was one of the best investments I have ever made. Now, I'm not sure how successful that business model is for them but personally I feel I would pay for uncapped download speeds and maybe some other nice QOL features. For a monthly fee, I would pay just when I am using the platform a lot. For a onetime expensive fee I would absolutely buy it if I can see myself using the platform well into the future (such is the case with Nexus mods for me.)

entries.platformsUseReasonAsModder:
I prefer Thunderstore, but I use them because for Valheim, it has a much better mod manager and you all at TS have been very very hands-on. I have barely heard anything out of Pickysaurus or the other nexus guys.

I started out doing both Nexus and TS uploads. I used Nexus at the time because it was more popular on a grand scale. It had more features in the UI and overall was more fleshed out on the site. However, I have found it almost better to tell people to come to discord for issues rather than posts on a site. Mainly because I would get the notifications much much quicker.

platformsUseReasonAsModderCategory.description: Responses focused on the platform being widely used or natively supported for a specific game.
Responses related to mod distribution methods, such as centralized locations or integration with particular programs.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser: The mod managers are simple. One click installations and way less cluttered or complex. Since using the mod manager to handle my Valheim mods I am able to help users debug issues 3-4 times as fast. Additionally, more mod authors also prefer TS mod managers. The nexus one (Vortex) isn't maintained for this game and they even get the BepInEx pack from Thunderstore about 4 weeks after it's updated on TS.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: Id MUCH rather a one time payment. subscriptions are AWFUL. But the main thing id consider is how often i use it. Thats why discord gets money from me and vrc never will. Another big one for me is how rude i see the company doing it is. Vrc has always been awful to free users. Treating them like there lesser and shit. Its also why i hate nexus and curse forge. Both feel insulting to me. Telegram has been pretty good about there system. Mostly because nothing changed for free users. The platform works exactly the same and Telegram isn't constantly nagging me to pay them. Its nice. Please if you do this, only ask people to pay ONCE. Any more and people get angry and refuse to buy out of spite. At least i do...

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: Consistency of pricing, ease of cancelation (meaning no nonsense with requiring some sort of email to a customer service rep to get it turned off.) transparency of how much the modders are being supported. entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
TBH I only use all of them because it is strictly necessary,

Steam Workshop
-Probably the best one, the games it has support for usually have in game setting and make things very simple. I do not recall a single issue with the steam workshop I've ever had.


Thunderstore 
-I wish you could view the websites entire description of mods on the mod manager itself

-I wish that it didn't eat so much ram because runs through overwolf. I have friends who REFUSE, and I mean straight up REFUSE to play anything modded from the Thunderstore, because they dont want to install overwolf. Its very annoying because the only thing I know that overwolf does is use processing power. I don't use it for anything and I've never heard of anyone using it for anything.

CurseForge

-Again, its redundant but, Overwolf kinda blows

-Only ever use it because its the only way for people who cant drag a couple files into their directory to play minecraft mods

-Would never touch it otherwise

Vortex/Nexus
-sucks cause it promotes user friendliness but disallows things like changing mod order past dragging ESLs down a list. Because its easy to break stuff they dont allow it. but that in turn makes it nearly impossible to do anything even slightly in depth when it comes to mods, because the inability to move the mod list as you see fit requires you to add exceptions directly in the code instead of in the mod manager

-Nexus itself is okay i guess, i hear that the management is bad and that they restrict content, like a mod that added a simple luger pistol was banned because of its use in WW2 by the germans, ive never had an issue with nexus mods but i hear about a lot of people disliking them

Mod.io
-only started using it recently because of the u12 update for blade and sorcery, but it works fine so far and i will keep using it as my main mod source for blade and sorcery

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser: Thunderstore is perfect. it is free, easy to use, and fast, has the ability to make multiple mod profiles, has the ablility to download other peoples modpacks and has a lot you can do with it in the options menu. the only bad thing is a bit of complex organization and not having every game. other than that it is perfect. Satisfactory mod manager is good like thunderstore but you cannot make multiple profiles and it only works for the game satisfactory. Curseforge is great but doesn't have the games i play. nexus is the worst thing ever created. it requires you to pay for fast downloads, and is overly complex. steam workshop is built into steam so its easy but it doesn't have multiple profiles and you can't download modpacks easily.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: if it was predatory (premium mods, unlimited download speed, features locked behind a paywall, etc) I would definitely not subscribe as a form of protest but if it was a bit of cosmetic stuff that doesn't improve the program (that would make it predatory), and/or no ads, and this magnificent mod manager needed it to stay up then I would definitely get a subscription.

subscriptionDecisionMainFactorCategory.description: Novel, unique, or compelling benefits offered by the subscription, such as increased download speed, no ads, bonus features, access to exclusive content, or voting on mod ideas

entries.platformsUseReasonAsModder: It is better curated and policed than like a Thunderstore, which allows stolen mods to be hosted with no avenue to report them. Along with mods hosting spyware and DRM that collects IP addresses and gaming platform information, in the form of keymanager in the valheim modding section.

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor:
There isn't one main factor, its a combination of the amount of mods they have + maintain, the content of those mods, and how well their mods work with other's mods. 

If I'm buying a subscription to a single one of Azumatt's mods, I probably wouldn't be paying very much. 

If I'm buying a subscription to the entirety of RandyKnapp's suite, I would be paying much more, as his mods generally provide much more content, and require more work to maintain than a single mod that provides customization for a small array of gameplay mechanics.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
'- Thunderstore:  Main hub the community uses for Risk of Rain 2 mods.
- Steam Workshop:  Games that have workshop support have communities that use it as the main modding hub.  It's UI could be a bit better though.
- CurseForge:  Minecraft mods.  If mod developers switched to Modrinth I would just use that; Curseforge UI can be a pain.
- Modrinth:  Nice UI and hub for all external Minecraft content (mods, resource packs, etc.)

entries.platformsUseReasonAsModder:
I think they are the best to use as a mod creator and as a user that consumes mods. 
Nexus Mods has extremely aberrant content administration and moderation, and as a user, comsumption is just the worst user experience that any website on the Internet could come up with. 
I would never publish anything to Nexus Mods.

Mod.io I haven't used, and I haven't made anything for a game that is in CurseForge, though I could see myself doing so.

platformsUseReasonAsModderCategory.description: Responses related to mod distribution methods, such as centralized locations or integration with particular programs.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
Steam Workshop should be obvious, Thunderstore is extremely straight-forward to use through a web browser but it has a mod manager that makes it even easier and can be used to share profiles to get up netgames running.
CurseForge is mainly for Minecraft but the web is easy to navegate and has plenty of tools to use to filter or organize mod search (the best, I'd say)
Nexusmods should just shut down as its service doesn't help anybody. No I didn't like a single bit the fact that I had to make an account to download mods, it wasn't funny the fact that they deactivated my account for "inactivity" and I had to reactivate it again, navigation is just the worst thing that could ever exist, even worse than the Steam Workshop, and its extremely creepy they keep a history of mods I've seen or not. The extremely questionable site administration regarding mods and content don't help their case. Downloading anything from Nexusmods is just a hassle, and searching for them is even more.
I just wish it could just shut down so every mod in there could be rereleased / uploaded in a better site.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
Steam Workshop is integrated into a game's core programming, and manages installations automatically from the steam interface. 

Nexus' vortex will inform the user on most games if any external programs are required and dependencies required if they're not installed.

Mod.io was only because Noita adds mods there but it's similar to Gamebanana where installation is done by the end-user manually.

CurseForge has plenty of outside tools to grab mods from it, and has an extensive history of mods for Minecraft from even my highschool days (2009-2013).

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: On just what it'd do, if it was to support the platform and those who use it, it'll meet my primary criteria. For faster speed as a paying user, it'd meet the second. But on no circumstance would I support paying for the mods to have access to them (excluding earlier access, that's fine). That'd go against the purpose of sharing a creation for the community, which is the core of a mod's purpose, to share the fun. I'd pay to support the developer of said mod, but having it be mandatory would defeat the idea of sharing.

entries.platformsUseReasonAsUser:
CurseForge for Minecraft and KSP
Nexusmods for most of my modding needs
Thunderstore for unity games
Steam Workshop is convenient so it is usually is where I get most mods for a game. 

CurseForge gets my lowest rating because most of the time finding when looking for specific mods it is just the worst. Only use it because of the MC and KSP mods. 3/10

Nexus is all around the best for most things 9/10

Thunderstore is very simple and easy to use. Finding things is usually quick. Maybe a mods of the month thing like nexus would be neat to see. 9/10

Steam Workshop. I hate using it. its search and sorting are awful to use. Unless you know 95% of the mods name its can be impossible to find what you are looking for. 3-4/10 ( couldn't decide)

entries.subscriptionDecisionMainFactor: The main reason I would ever get one is support. I love supporting the creators that add thousands of hours of content to my favorite games for free. I’m fine with supporting platforms that support those creators. I absolutely despise platforms that seek to make a monopoly over a modding scene, like CurseForge with Minecraft. I make mods for people to enjoy, so having a service that makes it harder for people to get my mods feels awful.
